content.text: A desk with a mass of 67.4 kg rests on a floor where the coefficient of static friction between the surfaces is 0.45. If this desk is placed on a ramp with an angle of 22.0 degrees to the horizontal, how much force must be applied to get the desk to move?

THOUGHT 0: Now the desk is on an inclined plane, which means part of its weight will be directed down the ramp. I need to find how much additional force is needed to overcome static friction and start the desk moving.
THOUGHT 1: I'll draw a free body diagram showing all forces acting on the desk on the inclined plane.
THOUGHT 2: The desk has a mass of 67.4 kg and the coefficient of static friction is 0.45 from problem #3. Using this information, I'll calculate all relevant forces.

THOUGHT 3: First, the weight of the desk:
$F_g = mg = (67.4 \text{ kg})(9.8 \text{ m/s}^2) = 660.52 \text{ N}$

THOUGHT 4: On an inclined plane, the weight has two components:
- Component perpendicular to the ramp: $F_{gy} = F_g \cos(\theta) = -(660.52 \text{ N})(\cos(22.0^{\circ})) = -612.42 \text{ N}$
- Component parallel to the ramp: $F_{gx} = F_g \sin(\theta) = (660.52 \text{ N})(\sin(22.0^{\circ})) = 247 \text{ N}$
The parallel component automatically tries to move the desk down the ramp.

THOUGHT 5: The normal force equals the perpendicular component of weight:
$F_N = -F_{gy} = -(-612.42 \text{ N}) = 612.42 \text{ N}$

THOUGHT 6: The maximum static friction force is:
$F_f = \mu_s \cdot F_N = (0.45)(612.42 \text{ N}) = 275.59 \text{ N}$
THOUGHT 7: Now I need to determine if the component of weight parallel to the ramp ($F_{gx} = 247 \text{ N}$) is enough to overcome the maximum static friction ($F_f = 275.59 \text{ N}$).

THOUGHT 8: Since $247 \text{ N} < 275.59 \text{ N}$, the component of weight alone is not enough to overcome static friction. I need to apply an additional force to get the desk moving. The additional force required is:
$F_{app} \text{ needed} = 275.59 \text{ N} - 247 \text{ N} = 28.59 \text{ N} \approx 29 \text{ N}$

ANSWER: To get the desk to start moving, a force of at least 29 N needs to be applied down the ramp (in addition to the component of the weight already acting in that direction). Alternatively, a total force of at least 275.59 N would be required in the downward direction along the ramp.
